ParentCompanyName: Metropolitan Water District of Southern California

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California (MWDSC) distributes drinking water to member water agencies throughout Southern California.  MWDSC provides approximately 60 percent of the drinking water used by nearly 16 million people living on the southern California coastal plain between Ventura County and the Mexican border.

Disinfection is a critical process used by MWDSC in the treatment of its drinking water.  Disinfection helps to protect public health by killing pathogens in the water and preventing the spread of waterborne diseases.  The use of chlorine as a disinfectant in the treatment of drinking water and wastewater has been the dominant disinfection method in the United States since it was introduced, around the beginning of this century.  MWDSC currently utilizes bulk chlorine for disinfection at all of its water treatment plants, including the Joseph Jensen Water Treatment Plant (Jensen Plant).

As one might expect from its superior disinfection properties, chlorine is a hazardous substance.  Thus, storing and handling chlorine can present a risk to employees and the public without proper precautions.  MWDSC regards safe practices in the storing and usage of chlorine to be of primary importance and has an excellent safety record with chlorine.  To further safe practices, MWDSC has constructed a Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility to contain all chlorine inside a building which is protected by vapor scrubbers.

Jensen Plant's chlorine storage and usage process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule (RMPR) and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulation.  Both of these regulations require submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  An integral part of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possible consequences in case of an accident and the actions, which will be taken

, by the facility in an emergency.

The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 
- Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
- General facility and regulated substances information.
- Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.
- Five-year accident history summary.
- Emergency response program summary.
- Planned changes to improve safety.

An RMP for the Jensen Plant Chlorination Facility was prepared and submitted to the EPA in June 2004, to comply with the five-year RMP update requirement.  As discussed in the Executive Summary of the June 2004 RMP submission under ??A?Planned Changes to Improve Safety,??A? MWDSC decided to modify the Jensen Plant Chlorination Facility with a chlorine containment and scrubbing system to capture and neutralize an accidental chlorine release.  The decision to install the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, which is equipped with two chlorine vapor scrubbing systems was made to further enhance safety and mitigate offsite consequences of an accidental chlorine release.  The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is now completed and the modified Chlorine System contained in that facility is in operation.

The information required in the RMP Executive Summary is provided below for the newly modified Chlorine System at the Jensen Plant.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The MWDSC accidental release prevention policy for chlorine involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPA's RMP Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response.  The Jensen Plant has an excellent safety record of chlorine use.

General Facility and Regulated Substance In

formation

The Joseph Jensen Water Treatment Plant (Jensen Plant) is located at 13100 Balboa Boulevard in Granada Hills, California.  The plant is situated south of the Golden State Freeway (I-15) and Antelope Valley Free (14) junction.  The facility was constructed in 1972 and covers 232 acres.  The plant is designed to treat drinking water, including disinfection with chlorine.  The facility currently stores and uses chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the RMPR and CalARP Program rules, as well as the Federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.

The Chlorine System at the Jensen Plant is composed of the following components: (1) a totally contained chlorine feed system to receive, store, and deliver liquid chlorine to the evaporators, chlorine expansion vessels, associated piping and valving, leak sensors and monitors, and instrumentation, (2) totally contained evaporators to convert the chlorine to gas for use in the chlorinators (evaporator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation), (3) totally contained chlorinators to regulate flow of chlorine gas under vacuum to the ejectors (chlorinator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation), (4) ejectors to mix the chlorine gas with service water and inject chlorine solution at application points throughout the plant, and (5) chlorine gas treatment systems for capture and neutralization of an accidental chlorine release in the contained areas (scrubbers, caustic soda, fans, pumps, and associated piping and valving).

The chlorine storage vessels are totally contained in the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility storage bays.

The process flow for the Chlorine System begins at the liquid chlorine angle valves located on the storage vessels in each storage bay, connected by flexible metallic hose to the fixed piping system.  Liquid chlorine is transferred by its own vapor pressure from an on-line storage vessel

in each storage bay to one or more evaporators in each evaporator room.

Each evaporator uses an electrically heated water bath to vaporize the liquid chlorine.  The chlorinators regulate the flow of chlorine gas (under vacuum) through venturi eduction to the ejectors.  The ejectors are located at various points throughout the facility, and introduce chlorine (under vacuum) into service water to form chlorine solution that subsequently mixes with the water supply at different stages of the treatment process for disinfection purposes.

The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is continuously monitored in the control room by video cameras and chlorine leak detectors. Chlorine leak detectors are provided in the storage bays, evaporator rooms, chlorinator room and pipe tunnels.  Based on the concentration and location of chlorine detected, the leak detection system will activate a succession of safety measures, beginning with visual and audible alarms, the start-up of the chlorine neutralization system and shut down of the normal ventilation system, and finally, automatically closing storage vessel liquid chlorine angle valve.  The alarms are annunciated at the chlorine alarm panel as well as at the operator??A?s console in the control room.  Once alerted, fully trained personnel will respond to assess the chlorine leak.  In addition, each storage vessel valve connecting to the process is provided with a remotely actuated (pneumatic) emergency shutoff system.  In case of a major chlorine leak, chlorine supply can be stopped almost instantaneously by closing the shutoff system, automatically or manually from any of three control panels: unloading platform, chlorine maintenance room, or control room.  Emergency showers and eyewash stations are also provided throughout the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility including the scrubber system.

A packed-bed chlorine gas scrubber system, consisting of two parallel scrubber units, is provided to neutralize an accide

ntal release of chlorine gas from either storage bay, evaporator room, or the chlorinator room.  Caustic soda (~20% concentration) is used as the scrubbing media.

The chlorine pressure reducing valves, leak detectors, and computer control system are connected to the uninterruptible power supply (UPS) system.  In the event power is lost at the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, an alarm will alert the control room.  The water treatment plant has an emergency generator system, which provides backup power to run the plant, including the Chlorine System and scrubber units, in the event of a power failure.

The control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through guarded security gates, which are closed after regular hours when the plant is patrolled by security guards.  The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is monitored by video cameras from the Control Room and has door alarms.  Process storage areas are further secured with a badge entry system by authorized employees only.

Finally, no chlorine releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (no deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Jensen Plant during the last five years.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Jensen Plant complies with Federal and State Process Safety Management requirements.  The Jensen Plant accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
- Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
- Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
- Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
- Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
- Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
-

Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
- High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.
- Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.

Chemical-specific prevention steps include a chlorine containment and scrubbing system to capture and neutralize an accidental chlorine release, availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine detectors and alarms, and remotely controlled shutoff device on the chlorine storage vessel that can be activated automatically or by remote control.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and MSDS sheets.

Equipment safety information was meticulously compiled on the chlorine process. Specifications for chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  Jensen Plant also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

Process Hazard Analysis 

In 1991, 1994, 1995, and 1998 detailed process hazard analyses (PHAs) were conducted for the chlorination system equipment and procedures.  The 1998 RMP PHA was further reviewed and updated in December 2003 as part of the five-year RMP Program update.  An additional PHA was conducted in January 2006 as part

of the chlorine containment and scrubber modification project (i.e., Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility design and construction) and will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there is a major change in the process.  A list of recommended actions was developed in January 2006 to further improve the chlorine safety and staff has evaluated these recommendations and is documenting the resolution of recommended actions.

An update of the March 1999 CalARP seismic risk assessment was completed in June 2004 based on Region 1 LEPC CalARP Seismic Update Guidance and recommendations were provided to Jensen Plant staff for their evaluation and implementation.  An additional seismic risk assessment was completed in August 2008 for the newly built Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility.

Operating Procedures

Jensen Plant maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the chlorine process.  The Jensen Plant ensures effective operating practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs.  Standard operating procedures (SOPs) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the chlorine system.  The operating procedures include connection/disconnection for chlorine storage vessel, start-up and shutdown for chlorine evaporators, after maintenance start-up for chlorine evaporators, maintenance shutdown for chlorine evaporators, start-up and shutdown for ejectors, start-up and shutdown for chlorinators, chlorine system emergency shutdown, start-up following an emergency shutdown, and temporary operations.  Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to correct or avoid deviations.  Jensen Plant updates procedures whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Such an update of operating procedures took place to incorporate

changes in chlorine operation associated with the chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.  Operating procedures will be developed and put in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line or changes made in the handling of chlorine equipment, and reconfiguration of the facilities.

 
Training 

Jensen Plant employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine process are trained in an overview of the process and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures. Jensen Plant ensures that each employee newly assigned to the process, is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties.  Jensen Plant training program includes four elements: (1) initial training and awareness training, (2) refresher training, (3) documentation, and (4) testing.  Each employee presently involved in operating the chlorine process has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  

Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the Jensen Plant ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in their Management of Change and/or Pre Startup Safety Review procedures.  Such an update of chlorine operations training took place together with the update of chlorine operating procedures to incorporate changes in chlorine operations associated with operating the chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.

Jensen Plant prepares and retains records of initial and refresher training, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person (s) administering

the training.

Contractors

Jensen Plant has procedures and policies in place that ensure that the contractors are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations to these process areas, and emergency response procedures, and are prepared to safely complete the work.  The contractors are informed, prior to the initiation of the work at the site, of the applicable provisions of the emergency response plan.  Jensen Plant holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the process area; controls access to the process areas, and evaluates the contractor's safety performance.

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

Jensen Plant ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new process covered by this regulation, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  Jensen Plant maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  Jensen Plant mechanical integrity program includes the following:

- Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment vendors, industry codes and practice, and prior operating experience.
- Implementation of the written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.
- Training of maintenance personnel in preventive maintenance program procedures; safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and safe use and application of special equipment and/or unique tools.

The Jensen Plant mechanical integrity program was updated to reflect all changes associated with the chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

Jensen Plant requires employees and contractors

to employ safe work practices when performing "hot work" in, on, or around the covered process.  Jensen Plant uses a permitting and training program to ensure hot work is monitored and conducted safely on or near a process involving chlorine.

Jensen Plant provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This system allows Jensen Plant staff to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or need training to be completed.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are conducted every 3 years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  The Jensen Plant assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.  This team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit are documented, and a plan is developed to resolve the recommendations and implement appropriate enhancements to the prevention program.  

Incident Investigation

Jensen Plant investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented.  An investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and added or used to revise operating and maintenance procedures.  There have been no such incidents involvi

ng the Jensen Plant chlorine system.

Five-year Accident History Summary

No chlorine releases that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Jensen Plant during the last five years.

Emergency Response Program Summary

MWD is currently a non-responding agency and relies on local public response agencies, such as the Los Angeles Fire Department, to handle an accidental chlorine releases. 
Jensen Plant coordinates with local response agencies (Los Angeles Fire
Department) to help ensure familiarity with the Jensen Plant Chlorine System and its emergency requirements. Conservatively trained Jensen Plant operations and maintenance employees will be available in the event of a chlorine emergency to provide technical support to fire department responders. Jensen developed an emergency action plan to ensure employee safety and to set up emergency notification procedures. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were previously identified for the chlorine process in 1991, 1994, 1995, 1998, and 2003, when Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) conducted under the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP) guidelines, Process Safety Management Program and Risk Management Program were prepared for the Jensen Plant.  These recommended actions have been evaluated and implemented as required.  The changes proposed, which have now been implemented, most prominent among them is a new Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility to contain all chlorine inside a building which is protected by vapor scrubbers, which are a significant additional safety enhancement and risk reduction measure. Further changes were identified in January 2006 and August 2008, when the process hazard and seismic risk analyses were updated to include the new chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.  These recommended actions have be
en evaluated and will be resolved in a timely fashion.
